The following Narrative was originally written without the least idea of publi- cation, for the Author's own amusement-a mere whim of the hour, "to perpetu- ate the remembrance of the thing," while it was fresh upon his mind; and ,to drive away ennui while a sailor on board the Chilian Brig of War "Achilles." At the solicitation of a few friends, it has recently been re-written in portions each week for the "Lincoln Miscellany." The task has been performed at such intervals as-the writer could spare fr'rm his daily labors, when his mind was har- assed with business matters :--le was, therefore, no less surprised than gratified, at the the indulgence and favor with which his hasty production was received during the course otf its pub ication in the "Miscellany." These pages have been printed in signatures weekly, just as they appeared in the paper, and if they are faulty. so be it.; the reader must supply the corrections, he being the only one who has had an opportunity to do so. These remarks are not presented to excuse errors, or avert criticism ; the writer is aware that he must bear the blame of the former, let him be guilty or not guil- ty; and he is quite willing to "bide the pelting storm" of the latter; his sole ob- ject having been-without any attempt at author-craft-to furnish those who re- quested, and others who may choose to read these "Rambles," a "plain, unvar- nished tale" of a sailor's adventures.
OPINIONS OF THE PRESS. "7 The Lincoln (Thomaston, Me,) Miscellany is Publishing an original and highly interesting work entitled "Rambles in Chili,and hfe among the Araucanian Indians," by an annonyrnous author. * * * We can heartly pronounce it a work of rare merit. It combines richness of description, with thrilling incidents and marvellous adventures; and abounds in well painted delineations of manners and customs, useful observations of society, and accurate geographical history. The unobtrusive interblendingof a racy humor with the general flow of the narra- tive, will give it a popularity but little inferior to "Melville's Typee." The Aran. canians are an independent race of Indians, inhabiting the southern part of Chili, whom the Spaniards have never yet conquered ; and any account ot them cannot fail of being highly interesting. The work is likely to be widely read. [Norfolk County Journal It is put forward as an authentic narrative, and many of the scenes appear too natural and life like to be an invention of the author. The very minuteness and novelty of the details-preserve it from the charge of being an imaginary work. It is, however, a striking proof of the fact that truth is stranger than fiction, being full of stirring adventures, vivid scenes. and hair breadth escapes. The writer has given a very spirited deseiption' of the country through which he fravelled, and his pen has lent to some of the scenes and things portrayed an indescribable charm. He appears desirous to remain incognito, and uses a ficti- tious cognomen. Upon the whole it is a book well worth reading, which in this age of literary inundation, is saving uch in its favor. [Weekly Mirror. It is a highly entertaining and instructive tale, giving a true and humorous de. lineation of the manners and custants of the Chilians ; a correct description of the scenery in and about the cities of Valparaiso and Talcahuano ; with a novel and interesting account of a three months sojourn 4rnong a nation of Idians, to. tally ignorant of any previous intercourse with white men. It opens with a sketch of sea life. The principal part of the work, however, is a true narrative of an actttl journey through the count'rv, by two fugitive sail- ors ; and the story of their adventures, reckless daring, and hair breadth escapes is another proof that "truth is stranger than fiction." Although with little pre' tension to author-craft, the narrative is embellished with some of the most excit- ing and romantic scenes imaginable, and again with others the most comical. It is full of marvellous adventures, perilous journeyings, and glowing pictures of sce- nery and luxuriant nature. [Miscellany. We have heard many commendations of it, as abounding in variety of incidents, d natural and lively description. [Lime Rock Gazette.
